prompt:
I have the following count table for an RNA-seq experiment, rows are genes and columns are samples, "Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx". The first column of the file is my gene names and the rest of the columns are samples. My annotation data is here  "SRP021193.colData.tsv", it contains sample annotations and rows of this matches the columns of count table, first column is the sample ids. Normalize counts, make two PCA plots for samples, one color coded samples by "group" and the other color coded by "LibrarySelection" in my annotation data.

response:
To accomplish this task, we will use the R programming language and the `DESeq2` package for count normalization and PCA analysis. 

Step 1: Load the required libraries and read the count table and annotation data.

```
# Load libraries
library(DESeq2)
library(readxl)

# Read the count table
count_table <- read_excel("Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx", sheet = 1)

# Read the annotation data
annotation_data <- read.delim("SRP021193.colData.tsv", sep = "\t")
```

Step 2: Perform count normalization using the DESeq2 package.

```
# Create a DESeqDataSet object
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = count_table[, -1], 
                              colData = annotation_data, 
                              design = ~ 1)

# Perform count normalization
dds <- DESeq(dds)
```

Step 3: Create the first PCA plot color coded by "group" in the annotation data.

```
# Perform PCA
pca <- prcomp(t(assay(dds)))

# Create a data frame with samples and groups
pca_data <- data.frame(PC1 = pca$x[, 1], PC2 = pca$x[, 2], Group = annotation_data$group)

# Create the PCA plot
pca_plot_group <- ggplot(pca_data, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = Group)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "PC1", y = "PC2", title = "PCA plot: Samples color coded by 'group'")
```

Step 4: Create the second PCA plot color coded by "LibrarySelection" in the annotation data.

```
# Create a data frame with samples and library selection
pca_data <- data.frame(PC1 = pca$x[, 1], PC2 = pca$x[, 2], LibrarySelection = annotation_data$LibrarySelection)

# Create the PCA plot
pca_plot_library <- ggplot(pca_data, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = LibrarySelection)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "PC1", y = "PC2", title = "PCA plot: Samples color coded by 'LibrarySelection'")
```

Step 5: Plot both PCA plots.

```
# Plot both PCA plots
grid.arrange(pca_plot_group, pca_plot_library, ncol = 2)
```

Here is the complete code:

```
# Load libraries
library(DESeq2)
library(readxl)
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

# Read the count table
count_table <- read_excel("Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx", sheet = 1)

# Read the annotation data
annotation_data <- read.delim("SRP021193.colData.tsv", sep = "\t")

# Create a DESeqDataSet object
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = count_table[, -1], 
                              colData = annotation_data, 
                              design = ~ 1)

# Perform count normalization
dds <- DESeq(dds)

# Perform PCA
pca <- prcomp(t(assay(dds)))

# Create a data frame with samples and groups
pca_data <- data.frame(PC1 = pca$x[, 1], PC2 = pca$x[, 2], Group = annotation_data$group)

# Create the PCA plot - Group
pca_plot_group <- ggplot(pca_data, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = Group)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "PC1", y = "PC2", title = "PCA plot: Samples color coded by 'group'")

# Create a data frame with samples and library selection
pca_data <- data.frame(PC1 = pca$x[, 1], PC2 = pca$x[, 2], LibrarySelection = annotation_data$LibrarySelection)

# Create the PCA plot - LibrarySelection
pca_plot_library <- ggplot(pca_data, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = LibrarySelection)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "PC1", y = "PC2", title = "PCA plot: Samples color coded by 'LibrarySelection'")

# Plot both PCA plots
grid.arrange(pca_plot_group, pca_plot_library, ncol = 2)
```

Please make sure to install the required packages (`DESeq2`, `readxl`, `ggplot2`, `gridExtra`) before running the code.
